facts.text: Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, members of joint Hindu family, owned certain plots of land including Nos. 170 and 74/1 in village Arazi Mafi Pandai.
Mahadeo died leaving widow Basera Kunwar, son Damodar Pande and daughter Mahura Kunwar. Sahdeo died leaving widow Sundra Kunwar.
On death of Damodar Pande, Ram Sewak Pande brought suit against Basera Kunwar and Sundra Kunwar for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar, which was dismissed.
On death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande (son of Ram Sewak) and Ganga Pande got names mutated in regard to the property.
Mahura Kunwar brought suit for possession of estate left by Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande, decreed on August 1, 1941.
Mahura Kunwar obtained possession through court on May 31, 1943, including plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.
Mahura Kunwar made application to Sub-Divisional Magistrate on February 25, 1950, for proceedings under s.145 CrPC against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.
Magistrate ordered attachment of land including plots 170 and 74/1; possession given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar on March 15, 1950.
Property under attachment from March 15, 1950, to December 18, 1950, comprising part of 1357 F and 1358 F.
s.145 proceedings ended December 18, 1950, in favour of Mahura Kunwar; possession established; Adit and Ganga restrained from interfering; attachment ended; possession handed back to Mahura Kunwar.
Adit Pande and Ganga Pande filed revision to District Magistrate, dismissed March 28, 1951; actual possession delivered in April 1951; stayed from December 1950 to April 1951.

Mahura Kunwar filed complaint July 31, 1951, in Court of Judicial Magistrate Ghazipur under s.218 IPC against appellant (Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai), alleging wrong entries in khasra of 1358 F for plots 170 and 74/1, entering Adit Pande in possession remarks column.
Case committed to Sessions Court, S.T. No. 11 of 1952; prosecution witnesses: Mahura Kunwar (PW1), Gouri Shankar (PW2), Naresh (PW3); defence: Adit Pande (DW1), Ram Swarup (DW2).

Accused's plea: Learned from Shubh Karan that Mahura won s.145 case, but found Adit Pande in possession on spot; did not act per Magistrate order as no order received; Mahura not in actual possession.
Sessions Judge convicted appellant under s.218 IPC, sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.200 fine or 4 months RI default, dated June 7, 1952.
Allahabad High Court confirmed conviction in Criminal Appeal No. 647 of 1952, judgment September 7, 1954.
Appellant framed khasra 1358 F incorrectly, entering 'qabiz badastur' (possession as before) in remarks column for Adit Pande.
Prosecution evidence: Delivery of possession to Mahura in April 1951 proved by her statement, Gauri Shankar, Naresh; Shubh Karan sowed barley and paddy.
Shubh Karan not examined as witness.
Actual physical possession to Mahura not till April 1951; during attachment, given to sapurdar Shubh Karan.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant, a Patwari and public servant, framed the khasra of 1358 F in respect of plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 incorrectly, knowing it to be incorrect, with intent to cause or knowing likely to cause undue loss to Smt. Mahura Kunwar, thereby committing offence under s.218 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Accused came to know from Shubh Karan of s.145 order in favour of Mahura, but found Adit Pande in actual possession on spot; did not receive Magistrate order; Mahura not in actual possession.
Sapurdar Shubh Karan never got possession from Adit Pande; Shubh Karan not examined; prosecution case not proved beyond doubt.

No proof of necessary intention under s.218 IPC; direct evidence lacking, circumstantial evidence meagre; entry for 1358 F could not cause loss to Mahura as s.145 decided Dec 1950, not relevant for s.16 U.P. Zamindari Act (requires 1356 F).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.218 IPC; s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Accused deliberately made wrong entries in khasra 1358 F for plots 170 and 74/1, entering Adit Pande in possession in remarks column, knowing incorrect to cause gain to Adit and loss to Mahura.
Delivery of possession to Mahura proved by her, Gauri Shankar, Naresh; Shubh Karan sowed crops; actual possession April 1951; accused knew of litigation.
Entries incorrect per Rule 60 U.P. Land Records Manual; made with view to injure Mahura.

court_reasoning.text: Courts below considered s.145 proceedings, but land attached and given to sapurdar Shubh Karan; actual possession to Mahura only April 1951; sapurdar not examined.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mahura not in actual physical possession before April 1951 during attachment.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution must prove: (1) knowingly framed incorrect record; (2) with intent/knowledge to cause loss/injury to public or Mahura. High Court found knowledge of litigation and incorrect entry, but insufficiency for conviction without proof of intention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Incorrectness alone insufficient; intention essential under s.218.

court_reasoning.text: No direct evidence of intention; circumstantial evidence meagre. Accused's case: sapurdar never got possession. Courts held for prosecution on possession, but intention not proved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution failed to prove criminal intention.

court_reasoning.text: Entry could not create evidence for s.145 (decided Dec 1950 before March entry); not for 1356 F so irrelevant for s.16 Zamindari Act.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to prove necessary criminal intention under s.218 IPC; no offence committed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Framing incorrect record as public servant with intent to cause loss/injury.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings for possession; attachment and sapurdar.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Records Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Preparation of khasras; entries per actual facts by inquiry and inspection by April 30.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Recorded occupant of 1356 F in possession deemed hereditary tenant; entry complained of for 1358 F irrelevant.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of conviction and sentence by Sessions Court and Allahabad High Court set aside; appellant acquitted of offence under s.218 IPC.

key_quotes.text: Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention with which the appellant made the entry complained of.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reason for acquittal: lack of proof of mens rea under s.218.

key_quotes.text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under s.218 has been committed by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding that essential element of intention not established.
